Turks are going to the polls today for general elections.
They're being held early this year after opposition protests backed by the Turkish military led to the annulment of presidential elections two months ago.
NPR's Ivan Watson has been to the polling stations today in Istanbul and he joins us.
Ivan, elections in the middle of summer vacation season, are they expecting a lot of voters out today?
Absolutely.
The Turks are usually take their elections very seriously.
They get more than 80 percent voter turnout.
And for this election, you had coastal resorts reporting that their occupancy rates are down 50 percent.
At the polling stations we visited, people were coming directly in from their holidays with packed suitcases because they feel this election is very important.
The country's very polarized due to last April's crisis over the failed presidential elections.
The frontrunner is the current prime minister.
He's described as a moderate Islamist.
Why is he so controversial in Turkey?
His name is Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
And under his rule for the past four and a half years, the Turkish economy has really grown dramatically.

But Erdogan has not been able to escape accusations from the opposition that he has a secret Islamist agenda to change the very strict secular system of government in what is an overwhelmingly Muslim country.
And that's where the dispute stemmed from last April when it looked like Erdogan's candidate would win the post of president and those elections were blocked.
Without fail, it's clear that Erdogan has widespread support among the poor or the working classes who tend to be more openly religious.
And that is something that scares the secular traditional elite of this country.

While this election is going on, the Turkish military is continuing to fight Kurdish separatists in the southeast of the country, and the military is threatening to pursue them across the border into northern Iraq.
Has this military situation become a campaign issue?
Yes.
The right wing Nationalist Movement Party, the MHP, is expected to win seats in parliament this year.
It hasn't been in the parliament for several years.
And yesterday, its leader at a rally here in Istanbul accused Erdogan of encouraging Kurdish separatist rebels - known as the PKK - encouraging them to kill Turkish soldiers in the southeast.
So they are using that to try to attract voters.

The irony here is, is that the Kurdish Party - political party that's accused of having links to the PKK separatists is also predicted to win seats in parliament for the first time in more that a decade since its members, its lawmakers were thrown in jail for speaking Kurdish in public.
So you could have a parliament in - after this election with both Turkish and Kurdish nationalists glaring at each other from across the aisle.
NPR's Ivan Watson reporting on today's general elections in Turkey.
Thanks a lot, Ivan.
You're welcome.
